metadata.title: Investigative Radiology Chest CT Findings in Patients with Corona Virus Disease 2019 and its Relationship with Clinical Features --Manuscript Draft-- Manuscript Number: IR-D-20-00109R1 Full Title: Chest CT Findings in Patients with Corona Virus Disease 2019 and its Relationship with Clinical Features

affiliation.institution: the Second Affiliated Hospital of Chongqing Medical University Chongqing

abstract.text: Objectives: To investigate the chest computed tomography (CT) findings in patients with confirmed corona virus disease 2019 and to evaluate its relationship with clinical features. Materials and Methods: Study sample consisted of 80 patients diagnosed as COVID-19 from January to February 2020. The chest CT images and clinical data were reviewed and the relationship between them was analyzed. Results: Totally 80 patients diagnosed with COVID-19 were included. With regards to the clinical manifestations, 58/80 (73%) of patients had cough, 61/80 (76%) of patients had high temperature levels. The most frequent CT abnormalities observed were ground glass opacity (GGO) (73/80 cases, 91%), consolidation (50/80 cases, 63%) and interlobular septal thickening (47/80, 59%). Most of the lesions were multiple, with an average of 12±6 lung segments involved. The most common involved lung segments were the dorsal segment of the right lower lobe (69/80, 86%), the posterior basal segment of the right lower lobe (68/80, 85%), the lateral basal segment of the right lower lobe (64/80, 80%), the dorsal segment of the left lower lobe (61/80, 76%) and the posterior basal segment of the left lower lobe (65/80, 81%). The average pulmonary inflammation index (PII) value was (34%±20%) for all the patients. Correlation analysis showed that the PII value was significantly correlated with the values of lymphocyte count, monocyte count, C-reactive protein, procalcitonin, days from illness onset and body temperature (p<0.05). Conclusion: The common chest CT findings of COVID-19 are multiple GGO, consolidation and interlobular septal thickening in both lungs, which are mostly distributed under the pleura. There are significant correlations between the degree of pulmonary inflammation and the main clinical symptoms and laboratory results. CT plays an important role in the diagnosis and evaluation of this emerging global health emergency.

Dear Dr. Val M. Runge, Thank you very much for your letter and advice. We also appreciate the constructive criticisms of the reviewers. This letter explains the changes made to the manuscript ' Chest CT Findings in Patients with 2019 Novel Coronavirus Infection and its in response to comments by the reviewers. A pointby-point summary of all revisions is at the end of this letter.
We hope that the revision is acceptable, and I look forward to hearing from you soon.

body_text.text: Answer: Compared with other types of pneumonia, COVID-19 seemed to cause milder symptoms and severer pulmonary changes on CT. For example, most of the patients had mild symptoms and mild temperature rise, but their lung manifestations were serious. For different COVID-19 patients, the changes of lung function showed significant correlations with their symptoms and laboratory test results. We have revised it to be more concise (Line 204-205). Our imaging time points and disease stages have been discussed in the revision (Line, 229-239).

Q.12 Page 10, second paragraph: Typo "….the the….." and "…the pulmonary interstitium have been involved" -> "has been involved" Page 11, second paragraph: "…we found the common chest CT findings of 2019-ncov infection are multiple GGO…," -> "…we found that common chest CT findings in COVID-19 include multiple GGO,…., with mostly subpleural distribution" "…involving only a relative small sample subjects" -> "…involving a small number of patients with proven SARS-CoV-2 infection" Answer: The sentences have been revised according to the Reviewer's suggestions (Line 246-247, 257-259, 262-264).

References Make sure to include some brand new publications (i.e. published in Radiology) in the reference list dealing with this topic, when submitting your revised manuscript. In particular, there is one paper published regarding the time course of changes on chest CT. Here, you could discuss how your patients / image data fit into the stage of the disease / the clinical symptoms. Answer: Several new publications have been added in the revised version (Line 217-218, 229-237). The paper published regarding the time course of changes on chest CT and our data of imaging time points and disease stages have been discussed in the revised version (Line, 229-239).

Soon afterwards, more 43 3 and morean increasing number of patients without being exposingexposed to the 44 animal market were foundstarted to grow exponetially, indicating a fact of 45 human-to-human transmissionthat human to human transmission is taking place. At 46 present, itthis kind of pneumonia has been confirmed as a new type of acute respiratory infectious disease caused by coronavirus infection. 2,3 However, it is not 48 clear how expeditiously and sustainablyeasy and sustainable the virus is to 49 spreadspreads from person to person. On 12 February, 2020, the International 50 Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) announced that the official classification 51 of the new coronavirus was severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 52 (SARS-CoV-2). The same day, the World Health Organization (WHO) announced the 53 same day that the official name of the disease caused by the virus iswas corona virus 54 disease 2019 (COVID-19)On January 12, 2020, the World Health Organization 55 (WHO) named it as 2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019-ncov or officially named by the 56 World Health Organization as coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)), and the 57 pneumonia caused by this pathogen was called new coronavirus pneumonia. FIGREF4.text: study sample consisted of 80 patients who had been diagnosed as 85 COVID-19SARS-CoV-22019-ncov infection in our hospitals (outside of the Wuhan 86 area) from January to February 2020 were included in the present study. Committee approval of our institutions. The, and the committees 88 waived the need for individual consent because ofdue to the retrospective nature of 89 the study. The inclusion criteria were: 1. epidemiological history -either 90 travel/residence history in Wuhan or exposure history to fevered patients from Wuhan 91 suffering from respiratory symptomswith respiratory symptoms from Wuhan within 92 14 days before the onset of illness; 2. laboratory diagnosis -1) real-time fluorescence 93 polymerase chain reaction revealed positive detection of SARS-CoV-2 in throat swabs 94 or lower respiratory tract; 2) the virus gene sequencing of respiratory or blood 95 samples is highly homologous with the known SARS-CoV-2. All Patientsthe patients 96 underwent thin-section CT at least one time.A) Have an epidemiological history; B) 97 Having one of the following etiological evidences: 1) Real time RT-PCR detection of 98 2019 ncov nucleic acid positive in respiratory or blood samples; 2) The virus gene 99 sequencing of respiratory or blood samples is highly homologous with the known new 100 coronavirus; . C) Patients who underwent CT examinations. The exclusion criteria 101 were another confirmed concomitant pulmonary pneumonia infection or coronavirus 102 infection. Children and pregnant women were also excluded infrom this study 103

FIGREF5.text: examinations were performedcarried out with an 16-row multidetector CT 121 scanner (Siemens Somatom Sensation; Siemens, Erlangen, Germany) using the 122 following parameters: 120 kVp, 150 mA, 1.5 mm collimation, 1.35:1 pitch, sharp 123 kernel smoothing (B80f), and reconstruction matrix of 512×512, slice thickness of 124 1.0mm, and high spatial resolution algorithm. All the patients were scanned in a 125 supine position during breath-holding at full inspiration. Thin-section CT images were 126 reconstructed with 1.0 mm collimation with a high spatial resolution algorithmhigh 127 spatial frequency algorithm. All CT images were evaluated using a lung window, with 128 a window level of -500 HU and window width of 1500 HU. Two certificated chest 129 radiologists with 10 and 8 years of experience independently reviewed the CT 130 images while they . They were blinded to the names and clinical data of the patients.

FIGREF6.text: imaging features were fully assessed and the following findings were 132 highlighted: ground glass opacity (GGO), consolidation, interlobular septal thickening, 133 bronchial wall thickening, subpleural line, lymph node enlargement, pleural effusion 134 and pericardial effusion in accordance with the standard morphologic descriptors 135 based on the Fleischner Society Nomenclature Committee recommendations and 136 similar studies. 7,8 AAs a rule, a consensus had to be reached between the 2 137 radiologists about the abnormalities, and discrepancies were reconciled and tackled 138 via. Discrepancies were solved by discussion. Specificly, the evaluation of the size 139 and extent of lung involvement was based on the segments of the lung anatomy: 10 140 segments in the right lung and 10 segments in the left lung (2 segments were 141 considered in the apicoposterior segment of the left upper lobe and 2 segments were 142 considered in the inferior front segment of the left lower lobe). According to the 143 evaluation criterion established by Chongqing Radiologist Association of China, the 144 pulmonary inflammation index (PII) was obtained from each patient. PII = 145 (Distribution score + Size score) / 40 *100% (Fig.1). Distribution score: scored score 146 according to the lesion distribution, one score for each lung segment, and 20 scores 147 for left and right lung. Lesion size score: scoredscore according to whether the lesion 148 occupiesoccupied more than 50% of the lung segment volume, one score for ≥ 50%, 149 and zero score for < 50%. Spearman's correlations were performed to evaluate the 150 relationships between the PII value and the clinical symptom and laboratory results of 151 the patients. All Statistical Analysis was performedconducted using Statistical 152 Package for Social Sciences software version 23.0 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA). P 8 values less than 0.05 were considered statistically significant.

All the patiens 159 aged 15-79 years with an average age of 44±11 years. 26/80 (33%) of patients were 160 smokers. 61/80 (76%) of patients had high temperature levels. 15/80 (18%) of patients 161 had comorbidities, 4/80 (5%) of patients had hypertension, 4/80 (5%) of patients had 162 diabetes, 3/80 (4%) of patients had COPD, 3/80 (3%) of patients had 163 immunosuppression (immunosuppressive drugs taking), 1/80 (1%) of patients had 164 heart disease (coronary heart disease). No patients had asthma or other chronic lung 165 disease. With regards to the clinical manifestations, 58/80 (73%) of patients had 166 cough, 11/80 (14%) of patients had expectoration, 5/80 (6%) of patients had chest 167 pain, 13/80 (16%) of patients had muscle ache, 7/80 (9%) of patients had abdominal 168 pain or diarrhea, 9/80 (11%) of patients had pharyngeal discomfort, 8/80 (10%) of 169 patients had dizziness or headache, 7/80 (9%) of patients had dyspnea and 3/80 of 170 patients (4%) had blood in sputum. On physical examination stastics, the median 171 oxygen saturation was 97% (IQR: 96%-98%), the average heart rate was 88.24± 172 11.67 bpm and the respiratory rate was 21.05 ±3.74 breaths/min. The average 173 systolic BP was 123.46 ± 14.19 mmHg, and the diastolic BP was 80.00 ± 174 9 14.04 mmHg. Regarding the laboratory data, the median leukocyte count was 5), respectively. The median C-reactive protein was 12.39 (IQR: 178 2.71-50.60) (mg/L) and the procalcitonin was 0.04 (IQR: 0.03-0.07) (ng/mL). Blood 179 gas analysis were performed in 40 patients. FIGREF8.text: were examined by chest CT 7±4 days after the onset of disease.All 80 185 patients were examined by chest CT in 7 ±4 days from the onset of the disease. In 186 chest CT images, 76/80 cases (95%) of the patients had abnormalities indicating the 187 pneumonia. The major CT abnormalities observed were GGO (ground glass opacity) 188 (73/80 cases, 91%), consolidation (50/80 cases, 63%) and interlobular septal 189 thickening (47/80, 59%) (Fig. 1). Besides that, 9/80 (11%) of patients had bronchial 190 wall thickening, 16/80 (20%) of patients had subpleural line, 5/80 (6%) of patients 191 had pleural effusion, 3/80 (4%) of patients had lymph node enlargement, 4/80 (5%) of 192 patients had pericardial effusion. The characteristic signs were "crazy paving sign" 193(23/80, 29%) and "spider web sign" (20/80, 25%) (Figure Fig. 2, 3). The "crazy194 paving pattern" was characterized by the reticular interlobular septa thickening within 195 the patchy GGO, which had been reported in Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome 10 (SARS) literatures. 9,10 The "spider web sign" was the first time we found and named 197 it. It showed a triangular or angular GGO under the pleura with the internal 198 interlobular septa thickened like a net. The adjacent pleura was pulled and formed a 199 spiderweb-like shapeis pulled and looks like a spider's web in the corner. Most of the 200 lesions were multiple, with an average of 12±6 lung segments involved. The lesions 201 showed subpleural distribution in 42/80 cases (53%), diffuse distribution in 7/80 cases 202 (9%), peribronchial distribution in 3/80 cases (4%) and mixed distribution in 24/80 203 cases (30%). The most common involved lung segments were the dorsal segment of 204 the right lower lobe (69/80, 86%), the posterior basal segment of the right lower lobe 205 (68/80, 85%), the lateral basal segment of the right lower lobe (64/80, 80%), the 206 dorsal segment of the left lower lobe (61/80,76%) and the posterior basal segment of 207 the left lower lobe (65,81%). The average PII value was (34%±20%) for all the 208 patients. Correlation analysis showed that the PII value was significantly correlated 209 with the values of lymphocyte count, monocyte count, C-reactive protein, 210 procalcitonin, days from illness onset and body temperature (continuous variable) 211 (p<0.05). The correlation coefficient values were -.260, -.258, .373, .273, .287, .544 212 respectively. The chest CT findings of the patients were shown in

FIGREF9.text: 19SARS-CoV-2 2019-nCoV infection , which is primarily transmitted by 216 contact between people and droplets, turns out to be a new disease of human beingsis 217 11 a new disease of human beings, which is transmitted mainly by contact between 218 people and droplets. Whether the novel coronavirus can spread in other ways is 219 unclear, although it could be detected in nasopharyngeal swabs, sputum, lower 220 respiratory secretions, blood, feces and other samples. Early identification and early 221 intervention are the keyvital to reduce the incidence and mortality of severe cases. In 222 this study, most patients were adults and there was no significant difference between 223 the numbers of either male orand female. Cough and fever were the most common 224 clinical symptoms. The incidence of expectoration, chest pain, muscle ache, 225 abdominal pain or diarrhea, pharyngeal discomfort, headache or dizziness and 226 dyspnea were less commonwere not popular. This is similar to other types of 227 coronavirus infections such as the SARS and Middle East Respiratory Syndrome 228 (MERS). 11-13 This implies that they can presumably be classifed asindicating that they 229 may belong to the same kind of infection and the target cells of 230 SARS-CoV-22019-nCoV may also be located in the lower respiratory tract. 231 For chest CT, 76 cases (95%) had abnormalities indicating the pneumonia. On the 232 whole, the CT changes of the lung were significantly heavier than the clinical 233 manifestations.in comparison withcompared with other types of pneumonia, 234 COVID-19 seemed to cause milder symptoms and severer pulmonary changes on CT. 235 Most of the patients had mild symptoms and mild temperature rise, but their lung 236 manifestations were serious. Multiple lesions were found in multiple segments and 237 lobes of both lungs, which was different from the bacterial pneumonia. In other words, 238 multiple Multiple and large lesions of two lungs involved simultaneouslyat the same 12 time is not generally spottedpopular in the typical bacterial pneumonia. 14,15 The most 240 common involved lung segments were the dorsal segment of the right lower lobe, the 241 posterior basal segment of the right lower lobe, the lateral basal segment of the right 242 lower lobe, the dorsal segment of the left lower lobe and the posterior basal segment 243 of the left lower lobe. There were significant correlations amongbetween the degree of 244 pulmonary inflammation and the main clinical symptoms and laboratory results. Our 245 results suggested that chest CT could be used to evaluate the severity of the disease 246 and playsplayed an important role in clinical practice. For CT features, GGO was the 247 most common of all the abnormalities, followed by consolidation and interlobular 248 septal thickening. This is consistent with the results of the recently published 249 studies. 16-18 OccasionallySometimes the subpleural line and bronchial wall thickening 250 could be seen. Pleural whereas pleura effusion, pericardial effusion or lymph node 251 enlargement were rare to identifywas rare. Some of the GGO was characterized by the 252 reticular interlobular septa thickening, which is was called "crazy paving pattern". It 253 resulted from the alveolar edema and interstitial inflammatory of acute lung injury, 254 which had bebeen reported in SARS. 9,10 In another situation, some of the GGO 255 showed a triangular or angular shape under the pleura with the internal interlobular 256 septa thickened like a net. The adjacent pleura is pulled and looks like a spider's web 257 was pulled and formed a spiderweb-like shape in the corner. Thus we named it "spider 258 web sign". But the pathological basis needs further pathological confirmation. It is a 259 specific sign for COVID-19, which has not been reported in other diseases in the 260 literature. At present, it is not clear whether it has clinical value in evaluating the 261 13 prognosis of patients. Recently, Pan et al have analyzed the time course of lung 262 changes in 21 mild patients with confirmed COVID-19. They found that the initial 263 lung manifestation was subpleural GGO which turned to consolidation two weeks 264 after the onset of the disease, and then the lesions were gradually absorbed, leaving a 265 wide range of GGO and subpleural parenchymal bands. 17 In another article, the 266 authors found that after 7 days of treatment for the mild patients, there was a 267 significant reduction in GGO on chest CT. On the 13th day after admission, most of 268 the ground glass disappeared. Our patients constituted a complete group with mild, 269 severe and critical types. 19 All patients completed CT examination within two days 270 after admission, which was 7 ± 4 days from the onset of the disease. 271 At present, to our knowledge, all patients have not been examined by pathology 272 in the world, so it is impossible to know the exact pathological manifestations of 273 COVID-19. However, accordingAccording to the morphological changes of the CT 274 features, pathological manifestations could be speculated although there iswas no 275 direct evidence. The ground glass density lesions could be caused by the exudation of 276 alveoli. The appearance of consolidation indicatesindicated that the alveoli wereare 277 completely filled by inflammatory exudation. The thickening of interlobular septum 278 indicatedindicates that the the pulmonary interstitium hashave been involved. In the 279 late stage of acute respiratory distress syndrome, diffuse alveolar and interstitium 280 damage may occuredoccur. 281 The COVID-19SARS-CoV-2 2019-ncov infection needs to be differentiated 282 from other diseases, such as SARS and MERS. They all showed multiple ground 14 glass shadows and solid lesions in both lungs, mainly distributed under the pleura, 284 which were difficult to distinguish. 16-1820-22 However, SARS and MERS had faster 285 disease progress and heavier lung damageshave faster and heavier disease progress 286 and lung damage than COVID-19SARS-CoV-2 2019-ncov infection did. On the other 287 handLikewise, COVID-19it should be distinguisheddifferentiated from other kinds of 288 viral pneumonia such as influenza virus, parainfluenza virus, adenovirus, respiratory 289 syncytial virus, rhinovirus, human metapneumovirus and mycoplasma pneumonia.

FIGREF18.text: Totally 80 patients diagnosed with COVID-19 were included. With regards 11 to the clinical manifestations, 58/80 (73%) of patients had cough, 61/80 (76%) of 12 patients had high temperature levels. The most frequent CT abnormalities observed 13 were ground glass opacity (GGO) (73/80 cases, 91%), consolidation (50/80 cases, 14 63%) and interlobular septal thickening (47/80, 59%). Most of the lesions were 15 multiple, with an average of 12±6 lung segments involved. The most common 16 involved lung segments were the dorsal segment of the right lower lobe (69/80, 86%), 17 the posterior basal segment of the right lower lobe (68/80, 85%), the lateral basal 18 segment of the right lower lobe (64/80, 80%), the dorsal segment of the left lower 19 lobe (61/80, 76%) and the posterior basal segment of the left lower lobe (65/80, 81%).20 The average pulmonary inflammation index (PII) value was (34%±20%) for all the 21 patients. Correlation analysis showed that the PII value was significantly correlated 22 Final Manuscript (Clean Copy and BLINDED)with the values of lymphocyte count, monocyte count, C-reactive protein, 23 procalcitonin, days from illness onset and body temperature (p<0.05).24 Conclusion: The common chest CT findings of COVID-19 are multiple GGO, 25 consolidation and interlobular septal thickening in both lungs, which are mostly 26 distributed under the pleura. There are significant correlations between the degree of 27 pulmonary inflammation and the main clinical symptoms and laboratory results. Soon 37 afterwards, an increasing number of patients without being exposed to the animal 38 market started to grow exponetially, indicating a fact of human-to-human 39 transmission. At present, this kind of pneumonia has been confirmed as a new type of 40 acute respiratory infectious disease caused by coronavirus infection. 2,3 However, it is 41 not clear how expeditiously and sustainably the virus spreads from person to person. 42 On 12 February, 2020, the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) 43 announced that the official classification of the new coronavirus was severe acute 44 respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). FIGREF19.text: The epidemic caused by the new coronavirus has become a public health emergency 52 of international concern. 53 The SARS-CoV-2 is a new strain of coronavirus which has never been found in 54 human body before. Common clinical symptoms of patients infected with 55 SARS-CoV-2 include fever fatigue and dry cough. Besides, a small number of 56 patients could have nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat or diarrhea. Furthermore, 57 in some aggravated cases, infection has led to severe acute respiratory syndrome, 58 renal failure, and even death. In severe cases patients present with dyspnea and / or 59 hypoxemia one week after the onset of the disease, and develop rapidly into acute 60 respiratory distress syndrome, septic shock, metabolic acidosis and coagulation 61 dysfunction which are hard to correct. Up to the present there is only limited data 62 available regarding the typical chest CT imaging findings in COVID-19. In this study,63 we retrospectively evaluated the chest CT findings in 80 patients with confirmed 64 COVID-19 and evaluate their relationship with the clinical features. study sample consisted of 80 patients who had been diagnosed as 69 COVID-19 in our hospitals (outside of the Wuhan area) from January to February 70 2020. This study received Ethics Committee approval of our institutions, and the 71 committees waived the need for individual consent due to the retrospective nature of 72 the study. The inclusion criteria were: 1. epidemiological history -either 73 travel/residence history in Wuhan or exposure history to fevered patients from Wuhan 74 suffering from respiratory symptoms within 14 days before the onset of illness; 2. 75 laboratory diagnosis -1) real-time fluorescence polymerase chain reaction revealed 76 positive detection of SARS-CoV-2 in throat swabs or lower respiratory tract; 2) the 77 virus gene sequencing of respiratory or blood samples is highly homologous with the 78 known SARS-CoV-2. All the patients underwent thin-section CT at least one time. 79 The exclusion criteria were another confirmed concomitant pulmonary pneumonia or 80 coronavirus infection. Children and pregnant women were also excluded from this 81 study 82 Clinical and laboratorial data were obtained from a detailed medical records 83 collected respectively in standardized form by two radiologists with 10 and 8 years 84 experience. The following clinical data of the patients were assessed: gender, age, 85 cough, expectoration, chest pain, muscle ache, abdominal pain or diarrhea, pharyngeal 86 discomfort, dyspnea, dizziness or headache, blood in sputum, and presence of 87 wall thickening, subpleural line, lymph node enlargement, pleural effusion and 110 pericardial effusion in accordance with the standard morphologic descriptors based on 111 the Fleischner Society Nomenclature Committee recommendations and similar 112 studies. 7,8 As a rule, a consensus had to be reached between the 2 radiologists about 113 the abnormalities, and discrepancies were reconciled and tackled via discussion. 114 Specificly, the evaluation of the size and extent of lung involvement was based on the 115 segments of the lung anatomy: 10 segments in the right lung and 10 segments in the 116 left lung (2 segments were considered in the apicoposterior segment of the left upper 117 lobe and 2 segments were considered in the inferior front segment of the left lower 118 lobe). According to the evaluation criterion established by Chongqing Radiologist 119 Association of China, the pulmonary inflammation index (PII) was obtained from 120 each patient. PII = (Distribution score + Size score) / 40 *100% (Fig.1). Distribution 121 score: scored according to the lesion distribution, one score for each lung segment, 122 and 20 scores for left and right lung. Lesion size score: scored according to whether 123 the lesion occupied more than 50% of the lung segment volume, one score for ≥ 50%, 124 and zero score for < 50%. Spearman's correlations were performed to evaluate the 125 relationships between the PII value and the clinical symptom and laboratory results of 126 the patients. All Statistical Analysis was conducted using Statistical Package for 127 Social Sciences software version 23.0 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA).

FIGREF20.text: pattern" was characterized by the reticular interlobular septa thickening within the 168 patchy GGO, which had been reported in Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)169    literatures. 9,10 The "spider web sign" was the first time we found and named it. It170 showed a triangular or angular GGO under the pleura with the internal interlobular 171 septa thickened like a net. The adjacent pleura was pulled and formed a 172 spiderweb-like shape in the corner. Most of the lesions were multiple, with an average 173 of 12±6 lung segments involved. The lesions showed subpleural distribution in 42/80 174 cases (53%), diffuse distribution in 7/80 cases (9%), peribronchial distribution in 3/80 175 cases (4%) and mixed distribution in 24/80 cases (30%). The most common involved 176 lung segments were the dorsal segment of the right lower lobe (69/80, 86%), the 177 posterior basal segment of the right lower lobe (68/80, 85%), the lateral basal segment 178 of the right lower lobe (64/80, 80%), the dorsal segment of the left lower lobe 179 (61/80,76%) and the posterior basal segment of the left lower lobe (65,81%). The 180 average PII value was (34%±20%) for all the patients. Correlation analysis showed 181 that the PII value was significantly correlated with the values of lymphocyte count, 182 monocyte count, C-reactive protein, procalcitonin, days from illness onset and body 183 temperature (continuous variable) (p<0.05). The correlation coefficient values were 184 -.260, -.258, .373, .273, .287, .544 respectively. The chest CT findings of the patients 185 were shown in

FIGREF21.text: 19, which is primarily transmitted by contact between people and droplets, 189 turns out to be a new disease of human beings. Whether the novel coronavirus can 190 spread in other ways is unclear, although it could be detected in nasopharyngeal 191 swabs, sputum, lower respiratory secretions, blood, feces and other samples. Early 192 identification and early intervention are vital to reduce the incidence and mortality of 193 severe cases. In this study, most patients were adults and there was no significant 194 difference between the numbers of either male or female. Cough and fever were the 195 most common clinical symptoms. The incidence of expectoration, chest pain, muscle ache, abdominal pain or diarrhea, pharyngeal discomfort, headache or dizziness and 197 dyspnea were less common. This is similar to other types of coronavirus infections 198 such as the SARS and Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS). 11-13 This implies 199 that they can presumably be classifed as the same kind of infection and the target cells 200 of SARS-CoV-2 may also be located in the lower respiratory tract. 201 For chest CT, 76 cases (95%) had abnormalities indicating the pneumonia. On the 202 whole, in comparison with other types of pneumonia, COVID-19 seemed to cause 203 milder symptoms and severer pulmonary changes on CT. Most of the patients had 204 mild symptoms and mild temperature rise, but their lung manifestations were serious. 205 Multiple lesions were found in multiple segments and lobes of both lungs, which was 206 different from the bacterial pneumonia. In other words, multiple and large lesions of 207 two lungs involved simultaneously is not generally spotted in the typical bacterial 208 pneumonia. 14,15 The most common involved lung segments were the dorsal segment 209 of the right lower lobe, the posterior basal segment of the right lower lobe, the lateral 210 basal segment of the right lower lobe, the dorsal segment of the left lower lobe and 211 the posterior basal segment of the left lower lobe. There were significant correlations 212 among the degree of pulmonary inflammation and the main clinical symptoms and 213 laboratory results. Our results suggested that chest CT could be used to evaluate the 214 severity of the disease and played an important role in clinical practice. For CT 215 features, GGO was the most common of all the abnormalities, followed by 216 consolidation and interlobular septal thickening. This is consistent with the results of 217 the recently published studies. 16-18 Occasionally the subpleural line and bronchial wall 218 thickening could be seen whereas pleura effusion, pericardial effusion or lymph node 219 enlargement were rare to identify. Some of the GGO was characterized by the 220 reticular interlobular septa thickening, which was called "crazy paving pattern". It 221 resulted from the alveolar edema and interstitial inflammatory of acute lung injury, 222 which had been reported in SARS. 9,10 In another situation, some of the GGO showed 223 a triangular or angular shape under the pleura with the internal interlobular septa 224 thickened like a net. The adjacent pleura was pulled and formed a spiderweb-like 225 shape in the corner. Thus we named it "spider web sign". But the pathological basis 226 needs further pathological confirmation. It is a specific sign for COVID-19, which has 227 not been reported in other diseases in the literature. At present, it is not clear whether 228 it has clinical value in evaluating the prognosis of patients. Recently, Pan et al have 229 analyzed the time course of lung changes in 21 mild patients with confirmed 230 COVID-19. They found that the initial lung manifestation was subpleural GGO which 231 turned to consolidation two weeks after the onset of the disease, and then the lesions 232 were gradually absorbed, leaving a wide range of GGO and subpleural parenchymal 233 bands. 17 In another article, the authors found that after 7 days of treatment for the mild 234 patients, there was a significant reduction in GGO on chest CT. On the 13th day after 235 admission, most of the ground glass disappeared. Our patients constituted a complete 236 group with mild, severe and critical types. 19 All patients completed CT examination 237 within two days after admission, which was 7 ± 4 days from the onset of the 238 disease. 239 At present, to our knowledge, all patients have not been examined by pathology 240 in the world, so it is impossible to know the exact pathological manifestations of 241 COVID-19. However, according to the morphological changes of the CT features, 242 pathological manifestations could be speculated although there was no direct evidence. 243 The ground glass density lesions could be caused by the exudation of alveoli. The 244 appearance of consolidation indicated that the alveoli were completely filled by 245 inflammatory exudation. The thickening of interlobular septum indicated that the the 246 pulmonary interstitium has been involved. In the late stage of acute respiratory 247 distress syndrome, diffuse alveolar and interstitium damage may occur. 248 The COVID-19 needs to be differentiated from other diseases, such as SARS and 249 MERS. They all showed multiple ground glass shadows and solid lesions in both 250 lungs, mainly distributed under the pleura, which were difficult to distinguish. 20-22 251 However, SARS and MERS had faster disease progress and heavier lung damages 252 than COVID-19 infection did. Likewise, COVID-19 should be distinguished from 253 other kinds of viral pneumonia such as influenza virus, parainfluenza virus, 254 adenovirus, respiratory syncytial virus, rhinovirus, human metapneumovirus and 255 mycoplasma pneumonia.

FIGREF22.text: 257 COVID-19 include multiple GGO, consolidation and interlobular septal thickening in 258 both lungs, with mostly subpleural distribution. There were significant correlations 259 among the degree of pulmonary inflammation and the main clinical symptoms and 260 laboratory results. CT played an important role in the diagnosis and evaluation of this 261 emerging global health emergency. Nevertheless, this study has three limitations. First 262 of all, this was a retrospective study involving a small number of patients with proven 263 SARS-CoV-2 infection. Secondly, none of the patients had a lung biopsy or autopsy 264 to reflect the histopathological changes. Thirdly, this study was a cross-sectional 265 study and we could not analyze the dynamic CT changes in different stages. In the 266 future work we will investigate the chest CT features of differential stages of 267 COVID-19 by using larger, more diverse samples. n (%), n/N (%), mean (SD), where N is the total number of patients with 353 available data. COVID-19 = Corona Virus Disease 2019 .

Ground glass opacity (GGO) (white triangle), consolidation 394 (white thick arrow) and interlobular septal thickening (white thin arrow) distributed 395 under the pleura were seen. Nine lung segments including the lateral basal segment, 396 posterior basal segment, posterior basal segment, anterior basal segment of the both 397 lower lobe, and the dorsal segment of the left inferior lobe were involved. In three 398 segments the lesions occupied more than 50% of the total volume. PII= (9+3)/40 *100%=30%.
